etymology.description: semantic: 皀 ‘ancient round-mouthed food vessel’ + 卩 ‘to kneel’ — to approach to eat; to come near.
etymology.interpretation: A kneeling figure beside a round-mouthed food vessel evokes someone coming close to eat, expressing the idea of approaching or immediacy. From this sense of nearness developed the discourse use “namely; that is,” marking immediate identification or equivalence.

examples.chinese: 我们的目标很明确，即提高效率(我們的目標很明確，即提高效率)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen de mùbiāo hěn míngquè, jí tígāo xiàolǜ.
examples.english: Our goal is clear, namely to improve efficiency.

examples.chinese: 结论简单，即方案不可行(結論簡單，即方案不可行)。
examples.pinyin: Jiélùn jiǎndān, jí fāng'àn bù kěxíng.
examples.english: The conclusion is simple, that is, the plan is not feasible.

examples.chinese: 她只有一个愿望，即早日回家(她只有一個願望，即早日回家)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhǐ yǒu yí gè yuànwàng, jí zǎorì huí jiā.
examples.english: She has only one wish, namely to return home soon.
